definitions.definition: money that somebody agrees to pay if a person accused of a crime does not appear at their trial. When bail has been arranged, the accused person is allowed to go free until the trial.
definitions.labels: (especially North American English)(especially US English)(especially North American English)(British English)(North American English)

examples.text: Can anyone **put up bail** for you?
He committed another offence while he was out on bail *(= after  had been agreed).
For very serious crimes, it is hard to get bail.
She couldn't get bail and now she's lost those 20 months she spent on remand.
She has been granted conditional bail.
Rosenthal is currently free on bail.
The accused were held without bail.
The police were successful in opposing bail.
They were released on police bail pending further enquiries.
He was sent to a bail hostel until the case came to court.

definitions.definition: either of the two small pieces of wood on top of each set of three wooden posts (called stumps)
to fail to appear at your trial after you have paid money to be allowed to go free until the trial

examples.text: He skipped bail and went on the run for two weeks.

wordOrigin: noun sense 1 Middle English: from Old French, literally ‘custody, jurisdiction’, from bailler ‘take charge of’, from Latin bajulare ‘bear a burden’. noun sense 2 Middle English (denoting the outer wall of a castle): from Old French baile ‘palisade, enclosure’, baillier ‘enclose’, perhaps from Latin baculum ‘rod, stick’.
